data.title: Fletcher, Louise Evelyn (or Eveline) (1878-1961)
data.meta_description: Henderson’s Greater Vancouver City Directory, 1918, page 518 (edited image). Louise Evelyn Fletcher was the widow of Christie West Fletcher. She lived at 996 Denman Street from 1918 to 1926. Early Life Louise Evelyn Fletcher was born Louise Evelyn Conway on July 3, 1878 in Yarmouth, Hampshire, England. Her parents were William and Jane Conway.…
data.text:
Louise Evelyn Fletcher was the widow of Christie West Fletcher. She lived at 996 Denman Street from 1918 to 1926.

Early Life

Louise Evelyn Fletcher was born Louise Evelyn Conway on July 3, 1878 in Yarmouth, Hampshire, England. Her parents were William and Jane Conway.

Marriage to Christie Fletcher

In 1908, in Wandsworth, London, England, Louise married Christie West Fletcher. He was born on December 12, 1874, in Kew, London, England. His parents were Charles and Lucy Fletcher. Charles Fletcher was a member of the London Stock Exchange.

Christie had attended Lord Williams’s Grammar School in Thame, Oxfordshire. He became an indigo planter in India and then he served with Lumsden’s Horse in the Boer War. He later became an electrician.

To Canada

In September 1909, Charles came to Canada. He travelled through Quebec City on his way to Whonnock, British Columbia.

In February 1911, Louise and her daughter, Lucy, travelled to Halifax, Nova Scotia, on the Tunisian. They were heading to Vancouver.

In Vancouver

From 1912 to 1915, the Fletchers lived on East 32 Avenue in Vancouver.

In 1912, they were at 141 East 32 Ave.; from 1913, they lived at 162 East 32 Ave.

Christie was an electrician with the British Columbia Electric Railway.

Military Service

In December 1914, Christie enlisted with the Canadian Expeditionary Force.

He served with the British Columbia Regiment of the Canadian Infantry.

He died in France on September 30, 1916.

Canadian Patriotic Fund

From about 1918 to 1923, Louise was an employee of the Canadian Patriotic Fund, which collected money to support the families of soldiers.

The Vancouver office of the fund was at number 326, 736 Granville Street.

Charles Herbert Bonnor (1870-1929), an accountant, was the local secretary of the fund.

There were many predecessors of the Canadian Patriotic Fund. During the Boer War, an association appeared in Ottawa to create a fund to look after wives, children and dependants who were separated at home from those serving in South Africa. Other purposes of the fund were to look after soldiers and their families when the soldiers became wounded or sick while serving, as well as the widows, orphans, and other dependants of soldiers who died. The federal parliament established a more formal corporation to support these objectives: An Act to incorporate the Canadian Patriotic Fund Association, Statutes of Canada, 1901, chapter 92; amended by Statutes of Canada, 1908, chapter 96; and Statutes of Canada, 1909, chapter 67.

Desmond Morton’s book, Fight or Pay, Soldiers’ Families in the Great War, Vancouver, University of British Columbia Press, 2004, describes the scheme in the First World War. With the leadership of Sir Herbert Ames of Montreal, the federal government established a Canadian Patriotic Fund in 1914. The fund used a combination of private and public money to support its activities.

Although the fund did help, it was not perfect. There were strong social pressures to contribute to the fund, although the contributors may have had very little themselves. Even so, many families did not receive enough to support them. The administrators of the payments often intruded into private family lives to determine appropriate levels of payments. The federal government eventually took over many aspects of support for families of military personnel.

When the Second World War began in 1939, the federal parliament passed legislation to create a new Canadian Patriotic Fund [The Canadian Patriotic Fund Act, 1939, Statutes of Canada, 1939 (Second Session), chapter 1.]

Louise’s Later Years

In the 1921 Canada census, Louise and her children, Lucy and Christie, were living at 996 Denman Street.

In the late 1920s, they were at apartment 10 at 920 Bidwell Street.

In the 1930s they lived in Douglas Lodge Apartments, at the northwest corner of Granville Street and West 12th Avenue.

In 1939, Louise went to England to visit Lucy, who had recently been married to Henry Stafford Challis.

To Australia

Louise and her son, Christie, later lived in Australia.

In 1954, Louise was with Christie and his wife, Betty, at 7 Allars Street in Eastwood [Denistone West] in New South Wales. Australia.

In 1958, Louise was in Waverley, East Sydney, New South Wales.

Louise died in South Australia on June 8, 1961.

Christie and Louise had the following children.

Lucy Evelyn Fletcher

Lucy Evelyn Fletcher was born in Wandsworth, London, England on March 27, 1909.

She lived with her mother in Vancouver until about 1938. According to some sources, Lucy attended the University of British Columbia. She also worked as a stenographer with the Canadian Bank of Commerce.

In 1938, in London, England, Lucy married Henry Stafford Challis, who was a chartered company secretary. He was born in White Hart Lane, Tottenham, Middlesex, England on October 29, 1910. His parents were Edward and Emma Challis. Edward Challis was a clerk for an umbrella manufacturer.

In 1939, Henry and Lucy were living in flat 15 at 29 Westbourne Terrace in Paddington, London.

During the Second World War, Henry served with the British military forces, and he flew briefly with the Royal Air Force.

In 1941, Lucy was one of five members of the Beaver Club who provided “genuine Canadian accents” in a British war propaganda movie called “49th Parallel.” (The movie was called “The Invaders” when it appeared in the United States.)

The Beaver Club was a gathering place and recreation centre for Canadian troops on leave or in camp in England during the Second World War.

The movie opened in Vancouver in January 1942.

The movie is available on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TftqNmFAHJE: “A World War II U-boat crew are stranded in northern Canada. To avoid internment, they must make their way to the border and get into the still-neutral U.S.”

From the mid-1940s, Henry Stafford Challis worked for a company sometimes known as Berger Paints in Calcutta, India.

In 1950, Lucy and her children, Stafford and Amanda, sailed from Southampton, England to Bombay, India.

In 1953 and 1956, Henry, Lucy, and Amanda travelled from London to Bombay.

Lucy died on March 14, 1967.

Henry died in Manchester, England on May 6, 2006.

Christie William Fletcher

Christie William Fletcher was born in Vancouver on September 13, 1913.

He lived in Vancouver with his mother until 1935.

While he was a student at the University of British Columbia, he was the treasurer of the Players’ Club and the sports editor at the Ubyssey, the university’s student newspaper. He graduated in 1935 with a Bachelor of Commerce degree.

To Australia

In 1938, in Mosman, New South Wales, Christie married Marcelle Stella Le Claire, an actor who was also known as Marcelle Marnay.

Marcelle was born in France on December 31, 1919. She was best known for her role in a 1936 Australian film called “Uncivilised” (spelled “Uncivilized” in North America).

Christie served with the Australian military forces during the Second World War.

In 1944, Marcelle was a beautician in Spit Junction, a suburb of Mosman, New South Wales.

Marcelle’s Marriage to Stu Mallon

It appears that Christie’s and Marcelle’s marriage ended in divorce.

By the mid-1940s, Marcelle was married to Stewart (sometimes “Stuart” or “Stu”) Eugene Mallon, who was a United States military serviceman. Stewart was born in Kansas City, Missouri on January 31, 1922.

Stewart had a colourful and sometimes troubled life. In 1940, he was working for the Western Pipe and Steel Company. (His father was a paymaster for the company.) He was upset over a failed love affair, and he tried to end his life by jumping from a ferry boat. A nearby water taxi rescued him.

Stewart had a boxing career before he went overseas with the United States military service.

In 1944, the South Australian Police Gazette reported that Stewart was absent from the United States Army.

His absence appears to have been resolved, because he later continued his military service.

Stewart continued his boxing career; he also became a hair stylist and clothing designer.

In May 1946, Stewart broke his jaw during a fight in Sydney, Australia.

By June 1947, Stewart (and probably Marcelle) had moved to California, where Stu resumed his boxing career for a time.

Marcelle became ill, and she died in San Mateo, California, on February 4, 1951.

Stuart later worked at a variety of jobs. He also had a series of legal difficulties involving assault and fraud.

Stewart married Rosetta Ross on August 4, 1952. They had a son, who was called Michael John Mallon and John Michael Ross.

Stewart and Rosetta lived briefly in Reno, Nevada.

Stewart’s and Rosetta’s marriage ended in divorce in Florida in 1957.

Stewart’s father, William D. Mallon, died in September 1958.

In 1974, a 50-year-old man named Stuart Mallon reported that he had been attacked and robbed in Santa Cruz, California.

Stuart died in Santa Cruz on November 11, 1984.

Christie Fletcher: Later Life.

In 1947, in Victoria, Australia, Christie married Betty Adele Hartley.

In 1977, Christie and Betty were living in Surfers Paradise in Queensland, Australia.

Betty died on January 12, 1986.

Christie died on December 31, 1992.

Christie William Fletcher and Marcelle Stella Le Claire had a son, Christie Conway Fletcher, who was born about 1938.

In October 1948, he travelled to Australia on Pan American Airways.

His destination was 587 Willoughby Road in Willoughby, New South Wales. In March 1948, Marie Elodie Geneviève Dubois (le Claire) (1889-1948) died at her sister’s residence at 587 Willoughby Road.

Christie may have returned to live with his mother in California.

He married Janice Fletcher. In the 1960s and 1970s, Christie and Janice Fletcher were living at 187 Ray Road, Epping, New South Wales.

In 1980, Christie and Janice were still at 187 Ray Road. Christie was working as a mercer.

Christie and Janice Fletcher had two daughters: Simone Fletcher and Emma Fletcher.

Sources

Thanks to Emma Fletcher for information on Christie Conway Fletcher.

Christie West Fletcher (husband of Louise Eveline Conway)

[GEN-OBIT] Obituary Daily Times v14No028, Walter E. Styles; https://lists.rootsweb.com/hyperkitty/list/gen-obit@rootsweb.com/thread/2382303/: “CHALLIS, Henry Stafford; 95; Manchester ENG; Guernsey P (GSY CHI); 2006-6-7; kbutle.” [Guernsey, Channel Islands]

Stafford Challis, obituary, by Hannah Barker, The Guardian, July25, 2006; https://www.theguardian.com/news/2006/jul/25/obituaries.readersobituaries

“In his later years Stafford Challis, who has died aged 95, gave great service to the financial section of Marie Curie Cancer Care and, as honorary treasurer, to his great love, the National Liberal Club – where he also sat on the general committee, and, to his particular satisfaction, the wine committee. He had devoted his working life to Berger Paints, in Britain and India.

Stafford was born in White Hart Lane, Tottenham, then largely rural. A lifelong Tottenham Hotspur fan, he recalled that when gas was installed in the family home, the fitter was Tommy Clay, then Spurs captain and an England international.

Stafford’s father died in 1919 and he and his brother supported their invalid mother until her death in the 1950s. Stafford joined the National Benzole Company, at 17, qualifying as a chartered secretary in the early 1930s.

In 1938 he married Lucy Fletcher, and during that decade he also learned to fly. During the second world war he flew briefly with the RAF, and had a “good” war – playing a lot of sport.

He worked for Berger in Calcutta from the mid-1940s. While there he served as president of the Chartered Secretaries of India. From 1963 until the mid-1970s he worked for Berger in London.

In 1998 he moved to Manchester to be near his daughter and became involved with the local Liberal Democrats. He cut a distinguished figure on the streets of Chorlton-cum-Hardy in his trademark trilby hat.

His wife’s death in 1967 was a great blow. He is survived by his son and daughter, four grandchildren and a great-grandson.”

Berger Paints, Wikipedia article; https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Berger_Paints.
